The Hopkins tennis team dropped one match and won one last
week, losing to Catholic University, 5 matches to 2 and beating
St. John, 7-0. Both matches were
played at Homewood, the first on
Friday and the second Saturday.
The contest with Catholic University was an impromptu affair,
not being scheduled and was arranged only on the spur of the
moment. Regan, playing number

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 30, 1926.

OUR OWN QUEENSBURY RULES
-.
By. half past eight this evening, the Juniors w-ill be :issembled at their banquets, and the Freshman-Sophomore banquet season will be in full swing. We have no intention of
indulging in a long discussion of the value or drawbacks of the
annual riots, or of delving into the bloody annals of past years
• a history of the famous spring sport.
in order to present
From the determined and confident way in which the
Freshmen have ,begun their campaign, they do not seem to
need any information as to what the objects of the game are
or how they are obtained. All that is left for us is to offer a
little advice. We counsel moderation.
The only way in which the Freshmen can learn about the
the fine points of the banquet season is from the stories of those
who have gone before them and on account of the unfortunate
limifations of human nature, these stories cannot always be
strictly depended upon. The achievements of the past always
look bigger than they really were. For instance a senior, recounting the exploits of his youth to a group of admiring
listeners may distinctly remember the time he killed three
sophomores, when as a matter of fact he only maimed one
(and a rather small one at that). If his memory has become a
little blurred in the -course of three years it is not his fault
and besides no one else -can remember- well enough- to -cheek alp •
on him. The season, then is not quite the brutual affair that
all the stories beginning "I rem' ember the time when ..." would
lead one to believe.
We would not have anybody believe that we are trying to
belittle the banquet season, or to deny that it is the greatest
fun in the world, or that it should be entered into whole-heartedly There are only two things that it will be well to bear in
mind. In t* he first place, the good name of the University
should be considered. On account of the location of the campus,
a great part of the warfare *ill be waged in the city. Whenever
it is not in direct conflict with the vital issues of the campaign,
encounters in the streets, which might lead some of the uninitiated citizens to believe that Hopkins students are a gang of
thugs, should be avoided.
The second thing to remember is that after all the whole
banquet season is only a game after all. In the heat of battle
it is easy for a man to forget this, and to do something he will
be sorry for afterward. Slugging and grudge fights are against
the spirit of the thing, and have always been barred.
1 hat's all there is to it. May the best class win. And
ren.1 mber—absolutely no biting in the - clinches.

PHARMACISTS

PHILOLOGICAL & SCIENTIFIC
PUBLICATIONS
23 S. Hanover St., Baltimore.

One of the great surprises of
the Penn Relays held at Philadelphia last week was the defeat
of Francis Hussey, Boston College star sprinter, who equaled
the indoor record for the hundred
yard dash last winter at the Hopkihs-Fifth Regiment games. Hester of Michigan won the hundred
in 10 1-10 seconds, while Hussey
was only able to place fourth.
The winning of the two-mile
race by Jimmy Loucks of Syracuse was another complete surprise. Victor Chapman, a sophomore at Wisconsin, who had won
the Western Conference indoor
two-mile last month, had been expected to lead the field easily, but
on the last lap he was overhauled
by the Syracuse runner, who won
by fully ten yards.
The University of Maryland,
with the famous quartet of Sheriff, Tkomas, Mathews and Endslow, won their mile relay against
Fordham and New- York University in the fast-time of 3.23 3-5s.

The Maryland tennis team -has
an opportunity to win the state
championship next week. Hopkins will be met at College Park
next Saturday, and since Maryland has beaten both St. Johns
and Western Maryland, if they
are victorions next week, they will
with this victory annex the state
championship.
As Hopkins lost two of the
matches played so far, the prospects of victory seem none too
bright. The plan of selecting a
team from the tennis ladder evidently is not a successful one. In
the match against Catholic University last Friday, which was
lost by the score of 7 to 2, the
team showed a distinct lack of
practice.
•
•
The combined Oxford-Cambridge
lacrosse team seems to have gotten
in the habit of losing, their last
game resulting in a 6-4 victory for
St. Stephens.
*
* •*
*
*
As was expected The lacrosse
game with Army, with the exception of the last fifteen minutes of
play, was one of the most closely
contested, played at Homewood in
the last few years. Superior stickwork and better ability to dodge
were the most important factors
of the success of •Jays, although
Robinson's speed and -accurate
shooting were instrumental. The
defense, probably the most experienced one in the East, played
an exceptionally strong game,
Army scoring only one earned
goal. The work of Gerstmeyer as
an extra, who not only kept his
man well covered but also scored
two goals himself, was especially
noteworthy..

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
Now that the student governInents at various universities are
drawing up the rules which will
control the first part of the camPus existence of the embryo classes'of 1930, it becomes evident that
in several cases the day of pelllaell class rushes is drawing to a
close. The freshmen of Midland
College advocate the substitution
Of a sports contest early in the
Year as the best method for detiding class .supremacy. They
condemn the traditional FroshSoph battles not on the grounds
of bodily danger to the particiPants, but as inciters. of personal
and class enmity.
Last Saturday, in ihe form of
au inter-class track meet, Yale
Put this new plan to the test. The
freshmen W011 by a score of 77-49,
and brought to light • promis:ng,
Inaterial for the varsity..
Through the work of the Interfraternity Council, the State of
Mississippi has been prevailed
.Upon to repeal a law made in 1912
Which prohibited college fraternities, says a note in The New Student. Chapters may now be inStalled under the control of a faculty committee, but none may own
a house for five years, in order
that all fraternities ma-y be placed
04 an equal footing.

A great deal of interest has been
aroused in intercollegiate circles
by the recommendation of the
tiarvard Student Council that its
big university be divided into six
4inaller colleges, on the syle of an
tnglish university. This suggestion was made in a report on edueation, following a similar action
at Bowdoin and• Dartmouth.
Small colleges of about three
hundred students each housed in
dormitories by themselves, were
recommended as offering the
greatest opportunities for greater
ocial development and social
Progress.
The Council, relates the New
tudent, further declared itself in
favor of limitation of freshmen,
411d keeping down the number of
Unassimilable".students to ten per
tent. of the entire body. It also
urged that the college lay more
4ress on the cultural development
0f undergraduates rather than on
'
mere wisdom."
This report was the . result of
4ve months study On the part of a
Ninnittee of ten undergraduates
ho conferred with faculty members and students, both of their
°Wu and other colleges, as well as
kith prominent educational authorities. Since the report has
Just been officially presented to
the university trustees it may be
oule* time before any decision is
.4unounced.

That Germany is receptive to
the League of Nations, pursuing
middle course between rash enthusiasm on the one hand and
an abhorrence on the other was the
thought expressed by Dr. Carl
Brinckmann, professor of politic-al science at the University of
Heidelberg, in a lecture on "Germany's attitude toward the League
Of Nations" given- at the Civil Engineering building on April 27.
In this period through which
the German government is passing there is wide divergence of
opinion concerning the League.
There is, however, a steady drift

toard the theory that Germany
shbuld take her place in the Dem.i
ora tic system ,.of
S.

for a war.
The League, however, Dr.
Brinckmann pointed out, shortly
began to develop differently from
what had originally been intended,
and from the Wilsonian policy
which it had at the start, it
seemed to become an instrument
in the hands of a few great Euro
pean powers. When Germany
saw this change it began to lose
hope of ever securing the solution
of the European affair. During
the period of the inflation of the
German currency the work of the
Dawes commission .had much to
do with bringing about a change
in this feeling. France, which before had objected to Germany's
entrance into the League, now
changed her policy, and encouraged this. In a, manner the Wilsonian character returned to the
League, and Germany was glad
to enter with some reservations.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 30, 1926.

OUR OWN QUEENSBURY RULES
-.
By. half past eight this evening, the Juniors w-ill be :issembled at their banquets, and the Freshman-Sophomore banquet season will be in full swing. We have no intention of
indulging in a long discussion of the value or drawbacks of the
annual riots, or of delving into the bloody annals of past years
• a history of the famous spring sport.
in order to present
From the determined and confident way in which the
Freshmen have ,begun their campaign, they do not seem to
need any information as to what the objects of the game are
or how they are obtained. All that is left for us is to offer a
little advice. We counsel moderation.
The only way in which the Freshmen can learn about the
the fine points of the banquet season is from the stories of those
who have gone before them and on account of the unfortunate
limifations of human nature, these stories cannot always be
strictly depended upon. The achievements of the past always
look bigger than they really were. For instance a senior, recounting the exploits of his youth to a group of admiring
listeners may distinctly remember the time he killed three
sophomores, when as a matter of fact he only maimed one
(and a rather small one at that). If his memory has become a
little blurred in the -course of three years it is not his fault
and besides no one else -can remember- well enough- to -cheek alp •
on him. The season, then is not quite the brutual affair that
all the stories beginning "I rem' ember the time when ..." would
lead one to believe.
We would not have anybody believe that we are trying to
belittle the banquet season, or to deny that it is the greatest
fun in the world, or that it should be entered into whole-heartedly There are only two things that it will be well to bear in
mind. In t* he first place, the good name of the University
should be considered. On account of the location of the campus,
a great part of the warfare *ill be waged in the city. Whenever
it is not in direct conflict with the vital issues of the campaign,
encounters in the streets, which might lead some of the uninitiated citizens to believe that Hopkins students are a gang of
thugs, should be avoided.
The second thing to remember is that after all the whole
banquet season is only a game after all. In the heat of battle
it is easy for a man to forget this, and to do something he will
be sorry for afterward. Slugging and grudge fights are against
the spirit of the thing, and have always been barred.
1 hat's all there is to it. May the best class win. And
ren.1 mber—absolutely no biting in the - clinches.

One of the great surprises of
the Penn Relays held at Philadelphia last week was the defeat
of Francis Hussey, Boston College star sprinter, who equaled
the indoor record for the hundred
yard dash last winter at the Hopkihs-Fifth Regiment games. Hester of Michigan won the hundred
in 10 1-10 seconds, while Hussey
was only able to place fourth.
The winning of the two-mile
race by Jimmy Loucks of Syracuse was another complete surprise. Victor Chapman, a sophomore at Wisconsin, who had won
the Western Conference indoor
two-mile last month, had been expected to lead the field easily, but
on the last lap he was overhauled
by the Syracuse runner, who won
by fully ten yards.
The University of Maryland,
with the famous quartet of Sheriff, Tkomas, Mathews and Endslow, won their mile relay against
Fordham and New- York University in the fast-time of 3.23 3-5s.

The Maryland tennis team -has
an opportunity to win the state
championship next week. Hopkins will be met at College Park
next Saturday, and since Maryland has beaten both St. Johns
and Western Maryland, if they
are victorions next week, they will
with this victory annex the state
championship.
As Hopkins lost two of the
matches played so far, the prospects of victory seem none too
bright. The plan of selecting a
team from the tennis ladder evidently is not a successful one. In
the match against Catholic University last Friday, which was
lost by the score of 7 to 2, the
team showed a distinct lack of
practice.
•
•
The combined Oxford-Cambridge
lacrosse team seems to have gotten
in the habit of losing, their last
game resulting in a 6-4 victory for
St. Stephens.
*
* •*
*
*
As was expected The lacrosse
game with Army, with the exception of the last fifteen minutes of
play, was one of the most closely
contested, played at Homewood in
the last few years. Superior stickwork and better ability to dodge
were the most important factors
of the success of •Jays, although
Robinson's speed and -accurate
shooting were instrumental. The
defense, probably the most experienced one in the East, played
an exceptionally strong game,
Army scoring only one earned
goal. The work of Gerstmeyer as
an extra, who not only kept his
man well covered but also scored
two goals himself, was especially
noteworthy..

Now that the student governInents at various universities are
drawing up the rules which will
control the first part of the camPus existence of the embryo classes'of 1930, it becomes evident that
in several cases the day of pelllaell class rushes is drawing to a
close. The freshmen of Midland
College advocate the substitution
Of a sports contest early in the
Year as the best method for detiding class .supremacy. They
condemn the traditional FroshSoph battles not on the grounds
of bodily danger to the particiPants, but as inciters. of personal
and class enmity.
Last Saturday, in ihe form of
au inter-class track meet, Yale
Put this new plan to the test. The
freshmen W011 by a score of 77-49,
and brought to light • promis:ng,
Inaterial for the varsity..
Through the work of the Interfraternity Council, the State of
Mississippi has been prevailed
.Upon to repeal a law made in 1912
Which prohibited college fraternities, says a note in The New Student. Chapters may now be inStalled under the control of a faculty committee, but none may own
a house for five years, in order
that all fraternities ma-y be placed
04 an equal footing.

oule* time before any decision is

That Germany is receptive to
the League of Nations, pursuing
middle course between rash enthusiasm on the one hand and
an abhorrence on the other was the
thought expressed by Dr. Carl
Brinckmann, professor of politic-al science at the University of
Heidelberg, in a lecture on "Germany's attitude toward the League
Of Nations" given- at the Civil Engineering building on April 27.
In this period through which
the German government is passing there is wide divergence of
opinion concerning the League.
There is, however, a steady drift

toard the theory that Germany
shbuld take her place in the Dem.i
ora tic system ,.of
S.

for a war.
The League, however, Dr.
Brinckmann pointed out, shortly
began to develop differently from
what had originally been intended,
and from the Wilsonian policy
which it had at the start, it
seemed to become an instrument
in the hands of a few great Euro
pean powers. When Germany
saw this change it began to lose
hope of ever securing the solution
of the European affair. During
the period of the inflation of the
German currency the work of the
Dawes commission .had much to
do with bringing about a change
in this feeling. France, which before had objected to Germany's
entrance into the League, now
changed her policy, and encouraged this. In a, manner the Wilsonian character returned to the
League, and Germany was glad
to enter with some reservations.
